titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I received a Letter from George. H Derby, brevet second Lieutenant of the Ordnance, whose admission as a Cadet at the West Point Academy, I had obtained by the favor of John Bell Secretary of War in 1842, and who has recently graduated 7th. of his Class, soliciting my influence to obtain for him a transfer from the Ordnance to the Corps of Topographical engineers— I called this morning at the Pension Office with some additional papers in support of the claim of Eleanor Shepherd, which I left with the Commissioner of Pensions— Then on Col J. J. Abert, was referred by him to Genl. Scott, who after some pour parler sent for Col Talcott and finally promised me that Lieut George. H. Derby should be transferred to the corps of Topographical engineers— In the House a Resolution was adopted to close debate on the Warehousing bill at noon this day— The debate itself was a mockery— The engrossment of the bill was carried 117. to 52— Grinnell and Winthrop voting for it— Ashmun, Hudson—D. P. King, Rockwell and Thompson with me voting against it. Abbott did not vote— It is the golden key toon the revenue The Bill was passed and returned without amendment to the Senate— Private Bills, from the Senate were then taken up 4. of which were passed— A Bill for the relief of Hariette Ward, widow of a Lieutenant in the Navy, produced a perfect anarchy of two hours and then was passed without further struggle Army Appropriation Bill— Disagreement between the two Houses— Conference could not agree— Senate adhere— Ashmun moved to recede by lost 67. to 69— Dromgoole excused from voting— House insist and ask a second conference— Amendments of Senate to the subtreasury bill referred to the Committee of Ways and Means The House adjourned— Evening visit from Mr. John Connell—

In the Hall of the House of Representatives, the Chaplain of the House preached his last Sermon for the Session, from Ecclesiastes 9.10—“Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might, for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom in the grave, whither thou goest”— Mr. Milburn is said to be blind but he has no appearance of it, at the Clerk’s table whence he speaks, and he walks without a guide— He was brought here from what is called the far West, and among the worshipers of the wilds passes for eloquent— His discourses consist of common place Calvanism without intolerance or dogmatism.— Quiet inoffensive, pious, moral but to judgment so far from eloquent that from my constant attendance, upon his ministrations on the Sabbath through this long Session there is not a thought which I have heard from him remaining in my memory— There was this morning a dedication of a new Baptist Church in E. Street, east of the Post Office—to which I received a printed Circular invitation from the Trustees, but which I did not attend— There was no service this afternoon at Saint John’s Church; and I believe none at the second Presbyterian, which is now without a Pastor— The change from the Summer to the Autumnal atmosphere commenced this day, a full fortnight earlier than usual, and with the change a corresponding one is promised of my health— I read a few pages of the philosophy of the plan of salvation. Calvanism in extremis— But I am yet the influence of indolence— Is it strenua inertia—

I received this morning from the adjutant General Jones a copy of an order from the War Department, transferring Brevet Lieutenant George. H. Derby, from the Ordnance Department to the Corps of Topographical Engineers Letter of 1st. August, from my Son, Offer for my house, in Hancock Street— House Representatives, United States, Washington Hunt, New York moved to suspend the rules, for an Amendment of the Constitution to make the President ineligible, for a second term and to prohibit members of Congress from being appointed to Office— Suspension of Rules, and even yeas and nays refused— Dodge of Iowa moved a gratuity from the contingent fund to the officers, clerks, messengers, and pages, & labourers, like that bestowed by the Senate, on theirs— Lost 75 to 77— Garrett Davis moved to suspend the rules, for a Committee of enquiry whether the Treasury Department is issuing paper money— Suspension of the Rules refused Martin of Wisconsin, moved a distribution of books to the members of this Congress, which have been furnished to the members of the last— Dromgoole moved to lay the Resolution on the table—lost 69 to 96. Distribution carried 89. to 93. Ligon moved to close debate on the French spoliation Bill, at 2 P.M. this day— Motion laid on the table— Veto of the River and Harbour Bill received from the President. Moderate debate thereon till the House adjourned— Visit from Elliot. C. Cowdin of Boston with an invitation in behalf of the Boston Mercantile Library association to deliver a Lecture before them next October which I promised conditionally, my health permitting— Subject our Country— Evening visits from Theodore— L— Moody, Archibald Campbell and his brother from Albany—

I received a Letter from J. B. Howard of 31. July, Walpole, Massachusetts with a Petition from him and 4 others with an alternative of separation by Mason’s and Dickson’s line— And a Letter from Mr. Washington Hunt, requesting an autograph for Mrs. Hunt— House of Representatives, United States— The Veto Message was resumed.— John Wentworth had moved an Amendment to Dromgoole’s motion to print the Veto Message to print with it parts of the President’s annual message to shew his inconsistency— After some debate the previous question was carried on the Vetoed Bill, the vote on which was 95 to 93. a majority but not two-thirds, so that the Bill was lost— French spoliation Bill— Hamlin moved to close the debate in one hour— Cobb moved to lay the Bill on the table, lost 68. to 113— Thurman McClelland Cobb occupied the whole hour against the bill and when the time for voting came a swarm of amendments to defeat the bill followed, all rejected— It was reported without amendment, under the previous question passed for engrossment 93. to 88. passed for enactment 94 to 87—and reconsideration refused 79 to 95— Relief from long and deep agitation— I went this Evening to the Astronomical Observatory to take a glance at the Moon near full [(]7th. 1:10. A.M.) through the Frauenhofer Refractor— Lieutenant Morey was not there— Mr. Hubbard was— I saw the Moon, Antaris, and Saturn— Three gentlemen, of whom one was a member with three Ladies were also there— I came home about 10. in the Evening— The Steamer Hibernia arrived yesterday morning at Boston— Left Liverpool 19. July— Whig ministry in England. Lord John Russell premier. Oregon Treaty ratified—

I received a Letter from Ben. P. Green, a son of Duff Green soliciting my aid, to carry through the House an item of appropriation for compensation as Chargé d’Affaires of United States at Mexico— And a Letter from George Joy, 18 July Pentonville— House of Representatives of United States— Among the bills, and amendments from the Senate were Amendments to Amendments of the House, upon the Senate Bill to reduce and graduate the price of public Lands to actual settlers— Brodhead moved to lay the Bill on the table— McClelland moved a call of the House—refused 56. to 113. and the bill was laid on the table 184 to 59— This was retaliation for the veto upon the River and Harbour Bill—but nothing more— It will not save the public Lands, but abandons to ruin the Northern and Eastern Harbours— I reached the House immediately after the vote was taken, and did not vote upon it— The amendments of the Senate to Subtreasury were after a feeble struggle all concurred in, and after the rejection of a motion by George Ashmun to lay the Bill on the table it was finally adopted 101. to 77— A Bill from the Senate to remit duties of the importation of Rail road iron was at the motion of Roberts of Missouri laid on the table 131. to 41— McKay moved several resolutions respecting the distribution of books, to members— Navy Appropriation Bill Committee rose for lack of Quorum— Adjourned by yeas and nays 74 to 63— Conversation with Elisha Whittlesey about Judge John McLean— Evening visits from Mr. and Mrs. Francis— B. Stockton and from Mrs. Talbot and her daughter Mary— I went to Mr. Frye’s with a Letter from M. Poe Baltimore proposing to rent the Columbia Mill for a Cotton Factory— The weather still continues very warm—

Fahrenheit 86 at Sunrise Blazing Sun all day long— Flat calm day and night— The very calenture of the Summer— Its effects upon me body and mind I cannot describe— I received a note from Miss Milligan with the present of a miniature, painted by her of my dear wife Also a Letter from Thomas. J. Smith,Mills Russell Co. Virginia 11. July 1846 published at Abingdon— Also from McLane the Sergeant-at-Arms, my account of compensation for the Session— At the House the Report of the Committee of Conference upon the Bill for the relief of Richard Elliot was received and adopted and the Bill was passed— That of the second Committee of conference on the Army Appropriation bill was also adopted and the Bill passed— The Civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill and the West Point Academy Bill were before the House, upon amendments between the two houses— A joint Resolution to pay for militia called out by General Gaines without law, passed as it came from the Senate, rejecting an addition proposed by Jacob Thompson— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Linn Boyd chairman, on the Bill reported by Hopkins for the establishment of 185 new Postmasters roades— Bill to establish a Government in the territory of Oregon— Debate on the boundary—none in the bill— Anti Slavery clause—carried Grant to Mary widow of Captain Gray failed 73. to 77— The bill passed— Committee of the whole Union. Tibbatts chairman. Peruvian indemnity bill debated— Committee discharged and Bill passed. I spoke 10 minutes on the bill to establish the Government of the Oregon Territory— Mrs. Albion— K. Parris and her daughter Julia, spent part, of this evening here—

I received a Letter from my old friend John Davis, late and many years Judge of United States District Court of Massachusetts— It all in his own handwriting, and almost illegible, but encloses 8 lines of verse full of calm, philosophical and pious resignation, under the decays of nature in the last stage of human life— My sympathies with him are more than fraternal— At the house the report of the second conference on the Army appropriation Bill was accepted and the Bill passed— The civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill was labouring with Amendments pile upon pile, between the two Houses— While discussing these Amendments the House took a recess from 3. to 5. P.M—and at the invitation of Mr. Grinnell I went and dined with him and his fellow lodgers at Mrs. Whitwell’s— Mrs. Grinnell, Mrs. Davis and all the Ladies of the Party are gone— There was a light shower with distant thunder, while we were at dinner— On returning to the House at 5 o’clock; I found the Speaker had resumed the Chair, but there was no quorum— I moved a call of the House which was carried— At the first roll called 109 and at the second 140. when further proceeding were suspended— The civil and diplomatic appropriation bill, was resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hopkins chairman and debated till 10. at Night, when the Committee rose, the previous Question was moved A motion by Dromgoole to adjourn was lost, and the same motion immediately after, by Hamlin was carried— I went and took up the my wife, Mrs. John Adams and her daughter, at the lodgings of Mr. and Mrs. Stockton, where they had spent the Evening—

Morning call from Lund Washington Senior, with an engraved portrait of General George Washington, which he seemed to think a novelty and wished a certificate from me of it as a likeness— It was the engraving of Trumbull’s Trenton portrait, of which I told him, I possessed a copy, purchased at the Hague, in May 1795, but I could not certify it as a strong likeness— C. P. Montgomery and George Green; were also here— House of Representatives, United States— The usual intercourse of conferances, upon disagreeing votes between the two houses, upon several bills occupied great part of the day, but the event, was a Message, asking an appropriation of two millions of dollars to negotiate a Peace with Mexico— Referred on Dromgoole’s motion to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Moses Norris of New Hampshire Chairman— McKay introduced a Bill—to Close debate— Recess from 3. to 5—action of the debate— Whig vacillation— Queer speeches on all sides, mixed motives and impulses— David Wilmot’s proviso— McKay at my suggestion modified his proposed Bill— Jos. R. Ingersoll substitute— David Wilmots proviso again, McKay’s modified Bill, with Wilmots proviso again reported to the House 77 to 59— Tibbatts moved to lay it on the table—lost 78. to 90— Wick, Barringer, Grider— Bill engrossed 85 to 73— Passed. Refusal to reconsider 70. to 83. McKay voted against the Bill and all the South—Whig or Democrat— Massachusetts Adams, Hudson Rockwell, Thompson, Winthrop, vote for the Bill— Abbot, Ashmun, Grinnell, D— P. King, did not vote— McKay moves to suspend 16th. joint rule, to send the Bill to the Senate— Carried— Adjourned ten minutes before 11. French spoliation Bill vetoed— When I came home I found Archibald Campbell and Isaac. H. Adams— Proclamation of the Oregon Treaty—

There was no preaching, at the Capitol, I attended the morning service at St John’s Church, where Mr. Pyne read the prayers for the ninth Sunday after Trinity, and preached from John 3.18. “He that believeth in him; is not condemned: but he that believeth not is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God”— The discourse was upon Faith, and disclosed to my mind no new idea— On Saturday 5 August 1809. I started from Charlestown for St Petersburg with my wife, and child, Charles F. and others. The next day 6 August 1809, was the ninth Sunday after Trinity and I read to my wife on board ship the service of that day—with an impression which is not effaced— And all the while we were in Europe we continued the practise— Mr. Pyne’s discourse was upon saving Faith— A perplexing subject— At 4 o’clock this afternoon I attended at the 2nd. Presbyterian church, where the Revd. Mr. Patten of the Columbia College, preached from Philippians 4.6. “Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication, with thanksgiving let your request be made known unto God”— The sermon was upon prayer, supplication unto thanksgiving— Mr. Patten made no remarks upon the injunction to be careful for nothing—which discloses and perhaps requires a qualifying commentary— The spirit of the Gospel is frequently monitory against the excess of worldly care, but it is only the excess which is forbidden to which the more selfish morality of Solomon might lead— To be careful for nothing is a hyperbole—a figure of speech often used by Jesus— We had evening visits from Mr. Moseley to take leave from Mr. Augustus—L. McCrea and Lieutenant George Thom—

Close of 1. Session 29. Congress— The Houses met at 8. oclock A.M. The adjournment was fixed at noon for the convenience of members, many of whom departed in the Railway Cars for Baltimore at that hour. The day like all days the last days of a Session of Congress, was a Chaos of confusion— It began by a Committee of the whole on the state of the Union—Howell Cobb chairman upon an amendment of the Senate to the Navy appropriation Bill— There was a large Majority to disagree to the Senate’s amendment, but no quorum voting— Cobb declared the disagreement carried, though Garrett Davis had called for a division and remonstrated that there was no quorum— Cobb rode rough shod over Garrett Davis, and was sustained in his false report by the Speaker John. W: Davis, who in mastery of Garrett Davis remonstrance, said he could receive nothing as done in Committee—but the report of the Chairman— He put the question of concurring with the Amendment of the Senate, which was rejected 84 to 48— The Bill afterwards passed, by a report from a Committee of Conference— So did the civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill— A joint Committee was appointed to inform the President, that the two houses would adjourn at Noon but they made no report— Sims of S.C. and W. W. Campbell of New York moved to take up the bill for the relief of Elizabeth Hamilton—but failed— As the hand of the Clock was on the line of 12. the Speaker declared the House adjourned to the first Monday in December— At that moment John Davis was prosing in the Senate about the two millions Peace bill, with David Wilmots anti slavery proviso, which thereby fell through— G Ashmun a Letter from Capt Guisinger— Kavasales was here. My Ladies spent the Evening at Mrs. Talbot’s— I joined them there and met there Mrs. Newman and Mrs. Thornton— Walk home— Mr. Larned was also there—
